title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines terms such as "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes by a rental company. It also defines terms like "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard" according to section 30102 of title 49, United States Code. The term "person" is defined as given in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. A "rental company" is a person engaged in renting or leasing 5 or more covered vehicles for rental or lease purposes. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with defects related to motor vehicle safety or noncompliance with safety standards, unless the issue has been fixed before the transaction. During a rental or lease period, a rental company must address notifications of defects in covered vehicles related to safety standards within 5 business days of receiving the notification. The rental company must promptly inform the renter of any safety-related defects in the vehicle and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the issue is resolved. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties for violations will be in accordance with the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission Act is incorporated into this Act. The Commission's authority is not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. Additionally, the State officer must notify the Federal Trade Commission of any civil action. The authorized State officer must notify the Federal Trade Commission in writing before initiating a civil action, including a copy of the complaint. If not feasible to provide prior notice, the State must notify immediately upon instituting the action. The Federal Trade Commission may intervene in the action upon receiving the required notice. The Federal Trade Commission may intervene in a civil action, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. State attorney generals can still exercise their powers and proceed in court for alleged violations. The authorized State officer can proceed in court for alleged violations of civil or criminal statutes. No separate suit can be brought if the same violation is already being addressed by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent individuals from seeking remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7. NATIONAL HIGHWAY TRAFFIC SAFETY ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON SALES OF MOTOR VEHICLES TO RENTAL COMPANIES WITHOUT STANDARD SAFETY FEATURES. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of this Act's enactment on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include descriptions of buying practices, implications on consumer safety, and recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions. The Administrator will provide recommendations for regulatory and legislative actions to protect consumers from unsafe practices in the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will report on sales of motor vehicles by rental companies with safety defects before recalls. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act on sales of rental vehicles that may have safety defects or not comply with safety standards. Rental companies must notify customers of potential defects on their website. The Act requires rental companies to inform customers about potential safety defects in vehicles, until the Secretary of Transportation orders a notification or the manufacturer alerts owners about defects. The Act mandates rental companies to disclose safety defects in vehicles to customers. The report required includes analysis of sales frequency, effects on consumers, and Administrator's recommendations for legislative action. A follow-up report is due within a year of the initial submission. The follow-up report, due within a year of the initial submission, will analyze sales of covered vehicles and provide recommendations for legislative action based on the period described in the previous report. The follow-up report will analyze differences in findings between the Administrator's reports, discuss the effects of the Act on sales of covered vehicles.
